headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. The company wil
componenttext:
Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. The company will not make detailed comments in addition to those provided in its annual report on Form 10-K, and letter to shareholders, which have been posted at the company's website, and will use this conference call to respond to questions.
Acting as moderator for the call will be Matt Downing. At this time, I will turn the call over to Mr. Downing.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question today is from Michael Zaremski with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question today is from Michael Zaremski with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: The 10-K cites 35,000 independent agencies. That's up from 30,000 in more recent years. Have the new agencies been a driver of the PIP growth? And I was curious what your penetration rate is among independent agencies.
componenttext: The 10-K cites 35,000 independent agencies. That's up from 30,000 in more recent years. Have the new agencies been a driver of the PIP growth? And I was curious what your penetration rate is among independent agencies.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mike, unfortunately the answer's probably not significant driver of growth. We obviously know agencies, agents and we've always sort of held to a number that we could reasonably represent was a fair representation. But every so often, we take a more detai
componenttext: Mike, unfortunately the answer's probably not significant driver of growth. We obviously know agencies, agents and we've always sort of held to a number that we could reasonably represent was a fair representation. But every so often, we take a more detailed senses and this has not changed, our form will change to report it's now, 35,000 is more representative than 30,000 which we used for a long time. So it's a little bit more of a consistent PI change, and not representing a feathered ship or a sudden increase in agent. So no to the driver of additional volume, but our independent agency channel overall has actually been doing quite nicely. So we're happy with that, but don't focus too much on the change in number. You'll see that number going forward as a much more representative number in our PR and general releases.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And lastly, policy life expectancy has been decreasing indirect despite Snapshot and Home Advantage, which I believe our bigger contributors in that channel. Could you talk about that? And also, what the driver of the increased life expectancy in ag
componenttext: Okay. And lastly, policy life expectancy has been decreasing indirect despite Snapshot and Home Advantage, which I believe our bigger contributors in that channel. Could you talk about that? And also, what the driver of the increased life expectancy in agency has been -- what's been behind that.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. PHA and Snapshot both remained positive. So unfortunately, when you have questions like this, it tends to be little pieces of data and sometimes hard to connect the dots, so I'll try to do that as best I can. We had taken a significant -- and we've
componenttext: Sure. PHA and Snapshot both remained positive. So unfortunately, when you have questions like this, it tends to be little pieces of data and sometimes hard to connect the dots, so I'll try to do that as best I can. We had taken a significant -- and we've talked about this in past calls, significant rating action in Florida. Now I point out one thing, and you might say well, just one state. Florida represents a significant chunk of our business, and therefore, it does matter. When those rate changes take place, which are unfortunately very necessary, they have a delayed effect on future renewals. And a large piece of the retrenchment on PLE, which we are certainly not happy with, is a result of our rate changes -- our necessary rate changes in Florida. We have sort of beaten ourselves up quite approximately to see if there was anything we were doing internally. And frankly, there were a few things that we were doing internally that also were destructive to our PLE. A couple of those were more specific the direct than they were to agency. So the results are as we report them, but I don't sense any systemic issue or major change between direct or agency. And as long as our rate levels remain adequate for certainly our large states, I would expect to see those stats to reverse themselves and come back to the levels that they were at. That's not anything other than my expectation. But the reason for the decline primarily, a price shock, a little bit more accentuated indirect, where we also have some things that we needed to fix with regard to build plans and some what we call on-boarding activities, where we bring the customers on board, some things that we could do considerably better. All of those are either remediated or very close to remediation.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And since you brought up Florida, the bills in the Florida House regarding PIP in the Senate, were those going to be good for auto insurers like Progressive?
componenttext: And since you brought up Florida, the bills in the Florida House regarding PIP in the Senate, were those going to be good for auto insurers like Progressive?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Though it's somewhat dangerous. I need a carrier of not speculating on political issues, but it's a very fair question. Florida PIP is not irrelevant relative to the state of the industry right now. So I'd say a couple of things. The House bill, I think,
componenttext: Though it's somewhat dangerous. I need a carrier of not speculating on political issues, but it's a very fair question. Florida PIP is not irrelevant relative to the state of the industry right now. So I'd say a couple of things. The House bill, I think, has more potential from our perspective. Obviously, people in Florida have to choose to do whatever they do. We do not tend to get particularly involved in legislative for fears. We offer our opinion, and our experience in data, whereas the Senate build does not do nearly as much as the House Bill. And Florida has, since the third and fourth District Court ruling, changed a level of understanding of reimbursement for PIP that we thought was well expressed by the legislature in 2008. They are now what is called ruling something other than that, which is causing some degree of disruption. And frankly, we have made some moves to incorporate some language in our policy contract that we think puts us in a relatively better position than many. But the likelihood of reform, I'm not even going to give you a probability on that. I would tell you that if the House Bill were the one to be ratified, let's set it and government, that will be more useful to us than the Senate Bill.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Brian. He also asked a little bit about the drivers of agency policy life expectancy increasing. There's a number of reasons, but one of the reasons would be, we're actually getting more quoting activity the preferred market or some policy,
componenttext: Mike, this is Brian. He also asked a little bit about the drivers of agency policy life expectancy increasing. There's a number of reasons, but one of the reasons would be, we're actually getting more quoting activity the preferred market or some policy, such that policy have a tendency or norm to stay with us longer. So that is, for us, a very good thing. And our agents are now quoting us more for those preferred type of risks.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: My question relates -- in terms of how you select Snapshot. I was wondering if you have any data you can share with us about the propensity or proportion of accidents, 6 months customers or 1 year customers or 2 year customers, what percentage of your acc
componenttext: My question relates -- in terms of how you select Snapshot. I was wondering if you have any data you can share with us about the propensity or proportion of accidents, 6 months customers or 1 year customers or 2 year customers, what percentage of your accident know comes from the customers as opposed to your legacy customers?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Josh, that is a very knowable. I don't know that as the level of specificity, I'd be comfortable answering right now. I'll tell you what. We will almost certainly be talking about Snapshot in a meaningful way at our next meeting. And so while you can reas
componenttext: Josh, that is a very knowable. I don't know that as the level of specificity, I'd be comfortable answering right now. I'll tell you what. We will almost certainly be talking about Snapshot in a meaningful way at our next meeting. And so while you can reasonably assume, as we have -- we and others have indicated that new business loss ratios typically exceed the renewal loss ratios, and therefore, there is a propensity for higher frequency in the first terminal policy. But all of that just rather, I think that we can give you more answer specifically and frankly, that's a reasonable question. So why don't we sort of take note of that and before that to June when I can give you a bit more of an answer that would be of some value to you.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me try and ask it another way, which is less -- about more direct. It seems that this quarter, Progressive had a pretty wide GAAP in terms of underwriting profitability compared with the competitors, yet we assume the average Snapshot customers
componenttext: Okay. Let me try and ask it another way, which is less -- about more direct. It seems that this quarter, Progressive had a pretty wide GAAP in terms of underwriting profitability compared with the competitors, yet we assume the average Snapshot customers probably a lower premium for policy customer than the average general pool customer. What might, if you guys want to speculate, what might be accounting for this?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, All right. Perhaps I was looking for the statistical other than the one in general.
componenttext: Okay, All right. Perhaps I was looking for the statistical other than the one in general.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would take it, by the way, if you have it.
componenttext: I would take it, by the way, if you have it.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: We have it. I just didn't have it at the top of mind. Let me try to answer your question, but give you several different points that are valuable. I think it's a little dangerous to jump to most recently reported results, and use open explanation for the
componenttext: We have it. I just didn't have it at the top of mind. Let me try to answer your question, but give you several different points that are valuable. I think it's a little dangerous to jump to most recently reported results, and use open explanation for the deltas. I mean I see the industry results as well as you do. Let me tell you one of the most important things that is happening with Snapshot. First of all, units that we're shipping in Snapshot continued to increase. We have not seen a plateauing of that. So this is not, in some cases, we've come off and others come up with ideas. They seem good, but they don't really comp. Clearly, Snapshot is something that is definitely commercial grade. There's no question about that in terms of the units that we're shipping, the customers showing interest and the percent of new customers that this is affecting, specifically indirect and with the slight decline now in agency. And I mentioned some of that in my letter. The most important thing to me is that the loss results matched with the pricing. Your assessment that frankly, we are giving relatively large discounts is an important assessment. It is extremely dangerous to give large discounts unless you have a very high certainty that you're matching the true loss costs. So now that we've developed a reasonable track record, and there has been some tuning, but I would say tuning not sort of mega-refinement to our discount structure, we are becoming very comparable that we are matching our loss results with the pure premium. Or the pure premium is being matched up, and things look good there. So we will continue, as you will see, in some of our other statistics, it is possible that average premiums will decline for a little bit. The issue is we're matching the loss costs with our price. Answers so far, and so far is a reasonably good measure, yes. Are we seeing other things that we hope to get from that? The customers that are coming to us disproportionately relative to other non-UBI, I quote UBI here as Snapshot, U.S.-based insurance, they typically have primarily insurance. We are seeing a group of customers who typically get higher levels of discounts tend to be -- or tend to have a higher propensity to come from carriers that are, let's just say, the three that are larger than us, we are getting a higher percentage of those customers in a higher discount peers than we might in a lower discount peers or in non-usage space. We have now credible data that those who come to us through Snapshot and get a discount are experiencing a meaningful increase in retention. We're not going to give out those specific numbers, but when I see meaningful, it's not 10 basis points. We're finding that our advertising that we had, actually I'll say we've been struggled a little bit in our earliest versions of advertising to try to get people understand what the Snapshot concept was and the relative ease with which they could install the unit, we've probably had a couple that was not as effective. Two of our more recent commercials have helped with that a great deal. And a lot of the mystery and sort of concern seems to have gone away. A couple other things that I can throw in since Snapshot really is on people's minds is that the algorithms, and I tried to reference some of this in our shareholders letter, the algorithm will continue to be a working problem progress for us. Obviously we don't change it over time, but we're doing R&D to figure out new things. And it is very clear to us that more data, a better ability to analyze it, different uses of the components that we can now measure. We mentioned some of those at the last IR meeting, are actually going to tribute to a revised algorithm in the future. And I suspect that, that will continue for quite some time, as we get to use this data in more and more intelligent ways. We've also referenced in the shareholder letter that the intellectual property that we have has been reviewed and upheld at the patent office including the issuance of a further patent, which is very, very directly describing what we're doing in the marketplace. So we're very thrilled with that. So Snapshot in general is working very well. I'd say it's commercial grade, and lots results that matched with the pricing, and that gives us great deal of confidence to keep pushing on this.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matt Heimmermann from JBMC.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matt Heimmermann from JBMC.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess just on Snapshot, and I apologize if you've covered this before. But can you give us a sense -- this is really following up on the letter where you talked about kind of the agency distribution having kind of embraced this at a lesser rate than dir
componenttext: I guess just on Snapshot, and I apologize if you've covered this before. But can you give us a sense -- this is really following up on the letter where you talked about kind of the agency distribution having kind of embraced this at a lesser rate than direct customers. But I would just be curious, is the Snapshot customer a customer that is predisposed to be a direct customer more so than in agency customer? I'm just trying to think about if that customer is more likely to be a direct customer, does that mean they're more likely to be somebody who would be attracted to Progressive anyway? I'm just trying to think about that dynamic as we think about the penetration of the product over time.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I think that calls for some speculation, which in this case, I'll give you mine, and that's what it is. So I don't think the customer per se is necessarily someone who has a propensity for one distribution or another. Most people w
componenttext: That's a good question. I think that calls for some speculation, which in this case, I'll give you mine, and that's what it is. So I don't think the customer per se is necessarily someone who has a propensity for one distribution or another. Most people want to be rated in their insurance verses who they are and how they're driving behaviors reflect or could affect in the premium. So I really don't sense that there's a structural reason why somebody would feel differently if they went to an agent versus direct as to their personal comfort with having their insurance rate reflect their driving behavior. I think that's pretty much uniform. Why the reason I made a comment I made, and having had a lot of years with agent, is recognizing that as small-business people, changes come to them, some stick, some don't stick. I think agency in general, and actually sort of probably will put myself in the category if we are one of them. I want to see something get a little bit more of a permanency and a maturity to it before I put that on my customers, knowing that I'm the one that has to go back later and say oh no, it didn't work. The company changed their minds and I have to rewrite or do whatever. So I think there is a period where agents want to just get a greater confidence that this is something that they can rely on, and that they can offer to their customers with some degree of certainty that is going to be in place for a period in time. Our ability to do that and use our direct channel as a leading indicator to test that and prove that proposition is actually terrific, because then we can go back to agents and sort of say here's our data. I think you can start to feel a little more confident. And we're already starting to see, it's still small, but as I predicted and I'm happy to give you meaningful updates without necessarily specific percentages as the year develops. But I'll be surprised if we don't see the agency adoption of this somewhat come up to parallel, the direct adoption, simply because it's really a consumer benefit and doesn't have specifics to distributions.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then the other issue I was trying to my arms around was just around the Home Advantage product. From the standpoint -- and I don't if this works to your benefit or detriment or maybe it doesn't matter. But obviously, homeowners is now,
componenttext: That's helpful. And then the other issue I was trying to my arms around was just around the Home Advantage product. From the standpoint -- and I don't if this works to your benefit or detriment or maybe it doesn't matter. But obviously, homeowners is now, from an industry perspective, is seeing a ton of pricing pressure. And it doesn't look like this is likely to be a one-year phenomenon as a lot of folks in the industry feel like the product is structurally underpriced and the cat experience of last year and late 2010 have probably weighed on that a bit. So I guess my question is your providers, do you get -- do you feel like what they are likely to do on the rate side is going to be in line with the industry or more or less aggressive? And how do you see their relative rate need or actions affecting the take-up rate for that product for the preferred customer, multiproduct customer?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. The carriers that we work with were all -- but none of them were immune to the issues from last year, period. It's silly to suggest otherwise. However, to a degree I think that they were probably on the lesser side of that, which is nice for them. An
componenttext: Yes. The carriers that we work with were all -- but none of them were immune to the issues from last year, period. It's silly to suggest otherwise. However, to a degree I think that they were probably on the lesser side of that, which is nice for them. And they will need to react. That's clearly their decision to make, but they will need to react. And in fact, if we go back to the very first question that was asked about direct and a little bit of policy life expectancy, there's probably a touch in there where we're seeing some rate increases for our PHA that has changed the relationship in order. So this is not something that is not intertwined, but all of our carriers are on top of it. We get nothing from them that suggests that they are any more concerned than any other reasonable homeowners company. And while they're taking some rate need, it looks like in all cases, we have open and viable markets. And the good here relative to being able to offer that is far greater than the concern around rate. In fact, I want them to take rate, because they're no use to me if they're not viable and profitable in meeting their own standards. And what's probably more important is that frankly, you're going to see a lot of customers experience changes in their homeowners rates, which is potentially another shock that forces people into the marketplace in general to shop. So while there is some negative on the balance sheet here, there's actually a fair amount of positive from our perspective that we have multiple carriers. They're all open for business. In fact, we've added a couple of carriers and we'll talk about that later. And our PHA strategy continues to us to be a very viable strategy. It continues to open up more of that preferred customer coming in through direct and there we can offer through agents. Brian already mentioned they're coming through the agency channel as well, and our retention continues to be great. So long winded way of saying, yes, they're affected, yes, they'll take rate, clearly there's a negative to that. It's important that they do that. They do it in a way that is meaningful for them and keeps them in business. My suspicion is we'll pick up something on the other side as the balance sheet there, as other companies need to take rate and perhaps people reevaluate both their auto and homeowner's package.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Josh Stirling from Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question is from Josh Stirling from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: So fourth quarter growth picked up in both channels. It will be helpful, just in line with your commentary on Snapshot, if you could give us a sense of how much Snapshot might be contributing to the reason year growth? And just sort of more generally, wou
componenttext: So fourth quarter growth picked up in both channels. It will be helpful, just in line with your commentary on Snapshot, if you could give us a sense of how much Snapshot might be contributing to the reason year growth? And just sort of more generally, would you talk about your advertising you're starting to work. And I'm wondering if primarily we should be seeing this as something that would actually drive inbound quotes in sort of greater response rates and direct and online?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Josh, to the agency channel, I would say, very modest. I can't give you a quantification of it, but I would not say Snapshot was the driver of the independent agency channel growth, which we saw nicely in the fourth quarter. I would suggest to you there t
componenttext: Josh, to the agency channel, I would say, very modest. I can't give you a quantification of it, but I would not say Snapshot was the driver of the independent agency channel growth, which we saw nicely in the fourth quarter. I would suggest to you there that, that is probably more a result of other people's rate actions. And as agents are in the position to sort of see those work are on a daily basis where they have, they can change their placement or possibly even renewals. I think that's a bigger driver that, as you know, that is a comparative rating environment. So when there are rate changes, that sort of comes through very quickly and agents can arbitrage to whichever carrier they think is appropriate as they're representing them. I'm sure they'll feel good about them. So if you have a rate that's beneficial, you'll likelihood to get the business. I think we're benefiting more from that. With regard to direct, I don't think there's any question that, as I said earlier, when I try to put a few data points out there about Snapshot, our advertising for Snapshot in what we call sort of rivals and work on Flo where Flo is actually sort of transposed into individual cars as a metaphor for the Snapshot device, that seems to have worked along with a little bit of reality built into our advertising where we see someone plug the device in and say that was pretty easy. Surprisingly, that would seem easier there in retrospect than they do when we're planning. But those clearly suggested to people that the Snapshot is something that they should try. How much new business we get from Snapshot versus other advertising is very difficult. And while I could sort of ramble on, I'm not going to say I can measure that specifically. I would say the likelihood of someone coming to Progressive and then showing interest in Snapshot, remember they get a quote and then decide to take the device. That seems to have been, as I said, the unit shipment on that continues to go up. We haven't seen the plateau on that. So the level of consumer acceptance is very high. And as we showed in our fourth quarter results, our new prospects seemed to be starting to gain some momentum. But I think that's more of a combination of both product, advertising and possibly even rate from other companies or perhaps people getting renewals with an increase.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. I guess the one follow-up -- that's very helpful. The one follow-up that I would make to -- I think in fairness, this is in part related to Josh's question. But it appears from what you said and what you guys have published publicly, you're gettin
componenttext: Got it. I guess the one follow-up -- that's very helpful. The one follow-up that I would make to -- I think in fairness, this is in part related to Josh's question. But it appears from what you said and what you guys have published publicly, you're getting better than average mix and it's clearly sort of better -- the calibration is positive on the suction side than with retention in the long run, it should make sense. The question on investors are short-term animals, so we're also trying to figure out is this in the near term, say the next 12 months, i.e. 24 months as you guys roll this out, should you be thinking of this as margin mutual, diluted or perhaps even accretive as we think about sort of power this model?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I won't comment on your -- what you said, but I will comment on that you think it's responsible. It's accretive on a number of customers. And not being disrespectful on that answer, I think we need to focus on bass Progressive is to focus on is more and m
componenttext: I won't comment on your -- what you said, but I will comment on that you think it's responsible. It's accretive on a number of customers. And not being disrespectful on that answer, I think we need to focus on bass Progressive is to focus on is more and more customers all the time and at the right premium. So when we offer these discounts, we would not clearly take book of business and say, let's just offer a big discount to it. That will be bullish. This has to be able to generate more customers, potentially, and as I indicated earlier, the mix seems to be suggesting more than potential, a set of customers that we might not otherwise have gotten. I believe fully that this is so profound in terms of rating that is offering a level of segmentation that hereto for hasn't really been seen, perhaps credit was the last thing that came close to that. And as this gets traction, and I'm just not talking about just a few people, it will build on itself by reputation. And my suspicion is that the volume, as long as we're priced at our target, we have not changed our targets in any way shape or form, we'll accommodate Snapshot or will just say they will subsidize for a while or any sort of things. So I wouldn't be looking for change in margin, based simply on Snapshot. As I said earlier, you might be looking and use some caution in interpreting average -- little average written premium. So we may have new business coming on at an average written premium long lower than we previously did. That doesn't worry me nearly as much as it would be if we weren't matching lost costs with a premium.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Josh, this is Brian. I would add on is certainly, there's the new customer traction. There's also the long-term benefit of keeping them longer, which we clearly have seen even in our initial data that those who receive a discount participate get -- stay w
componenttext: Josh, this is Brian. I would add on is certainly, there's the new customer traction. There's also the long-term benefit of keeping them longer, which we clearly have seen even in our initial data that those who receive a discount participate get -- stay with us longer. So there is this long-term premium gains. And the pricing segmentation is very important, and we are always trying to price towards actual lost cost. And I think as we get closer and closer to those in terms of how we moves be reflective of what we believe lost cost will be. And if we can out segment our competition and have greater pricing urgency I think in the long term, we'll win on that front. It's just continuing our emphasis on price segmentation, pricing skills, having a low-cost strategy. And if we do both, we think our prices in the marketplace will be very competitive going forward.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: One other element of course that goes into the combined ratio is the expense ratio. So we fully appreciate and understand every written premium. I'd love to have that be higher because of the great leverage on expenses. But as Brian indicated, retention i
componenttext: One other element of course that goes into the combined ratio is the expense ratio. So we fully appreciate and understand every written premium. I'd love to have that be higher because of the great leverage on expenses. But as Brian indicated, retention is a much more powerful animal lare, both through expense ratio and frankly long-term margin. So I will tell you, you might be best thinking of margin as neutral because we're not compromising at all the upside to margin may incur while it relates more to the retention directly.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Vinay Misquith from Evercore Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is from Vinay Misquith from Evercore Partners.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: The first question, just to follow up on Snapshot. Just wanted to clarify the economics of the business. So for the existing customers who already have a Progressive insurance policy, wouldn't that be margined diluted for the good customers? And can you r
componenttext: The first question, just to follow up on Snapshot. Just wanted to clarify the economics of the business. So for the existing customers who already have a Progressive insurance policy, wouldn't that be margined diluted for the good customers? And can you really raise rates for those drivers who you identify as being bad drivers? I mean, for the new customers also, wouldn't the Snapshot mean lower margins for the best drivers? And can you really raise rates or charge higher pricing for the bad drivers?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] You want to take a shot on that? You ask a very, very, very important question, and one that I am going to answer as best I can for you, and it maybe that this is one that requires a little bit more graphical support. So our next meeting m
componenttext:
[indiscernible] You want to take a shot on that? You ask a very, very, very important question, and one that I am going to answer as best I can for you, and it maybe that this is one that requires a little bit more graphical support. So our next meeting might be even a better opportunity to do it. First of all, our existing customers are written under a contract that goes on, so we're not going to all our existing customers and changing their rates that we don't have the data to do that. We don't have a driving school. So when you implement anything, as much as we might like it to be different, when you implement something, you have to draw a line and say people going forward will be of this contract and get advantage at this price. We have no idea of the driving school of our installed base of customers, and they're not showing any great propensity to reevaluate or come back or whatever. They're free to do that. We do have some enforcement behavior when someone says, I see it on television and say I'd like that. And of course, we'll never withhold that for many customer. But that really is not a big issue. But if you extrapolated that and to a discount across the entire book, then we know what the outcome of that will be. With regards to new customers, we'll keep relatively simple and I said in my letter that we're no longer going to get the specific numbers. But let's say x customers come to us and tries Snapshot and we offer no discount. X is considerably smaller than y here, y would be the customers that come to us try Snapshot and get some level of discount. Those customers we're obviously very happy with us. The x customers, if 0 was the right answer, then we're in different. We would have sold them the policy in that anyway.
There's a good chance that it was in 0. It would've our estimation plus z. We understand plus z. We understand that we have the price this in total to balance out both with the current book and the level of discount we give new customers. So we want to be able to give as much as possible, but we recognize we have a factor that we're not pricing forward. And over time, that will balance out. I would tell you that the way I'd describe it and I don't know if it's worked particular well, but I describe it as it is important, but it is raining in the ocean. And we can make that up on a relatively small adjustment to the pricing we give across the book or in the discount structure. Hopefully that helps. If not, we will try in a more elaborate way in June.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's certainly very helpful. My second question was on the new apps decline, and that declined by 2% last year. I'm just curious about whether that was more related to Progressive being more disciplined than peers? And are you seeing peers now raising r
componenttext: That's certainly very helpful. My second question was on the new apps decline, and that declined by 2% last year. I'm just curious about whether that was more related to Progressive being more disciplined than peers? And are you seeing peers now raising rates as we saw some in the fourth quarter of last year? And also curious to what you're seeing with your largest direct competitor in terms of raising rates?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd certainly like to say discipline, but that's for you to decide. I have a little grid to that put together here. Matt puts it together and sort of growth and profitability, and obviously you're all familiar with those kinds of grid and being on th
componenttext: Yes, I'd certainly like to say discipline, but that's for you to decide. I have a little grid to that put together here. Matt puts it together and sort of growth and profitability, and obviously you're all familiar with those kinds of grid and being on the top right in this case is a place where you're growing and have great profitability. I want to anocdate that grid, because it depends on time frames. And it's amazing how few stay in that sector and how many go in and out of that sector. So the one thing I'd say to you is the growth and profitability clearly are audited, it's not always clear the timeframe in which they are audit. So we believe we have rates that are properly set for the most of the year. We did see some favorable development that probably was more than expected. Nonetheless, we had the discipline to stay with those rates in the early part of the year. We think their shopping behavior was down, and we may not have had quite the conversion rate that we could have had, but the discipline seemed to pay off as we went closer into the fourth quarter. And trends, which we think we had price for were being realized by others. Across the board, it seems that there is more propensity for rate increases than decreases. As I mentioned before, as possibly one of the reasons we're seeing an increase in volume in the fourth quarter. Did I answer your question?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: One last thing if I may. You're marketing spend and technology spend was up especially within the direct segment. We expect that to be on the rising trend, or you expect the expense ratio within the direct to dig down this year versus last year?
componenttext: One last thing if I may. You're marketing spend and technology spend was up especially within the direct segment. We expect that to be on the rising trend, or you expect the expense ratio within the direct to dig down this year versus last year?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: You want to take that one?
componenttext: You want to take that one?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I will speak for is the advertising spend. We do plan to continue to increase advertising spend, but that is always subject to our own assessment of the yield on that, and we talked about that for a fair number of times. But currently replaced with the yi
componenttext: I will speak for is the advertising spend. We do plan to continue to increase advertising spend, but that is always subject to our own assessment of the yield on that, and we talked about that for a fair number of times. But currently replaced with the yield in terms of acquisition cost and cost per sale as well as some of the other what we might call brand health measures of consideration and preference, et cetera. So right now, we feel good about our ad spend and we do plan to continue to have that increase. It may not increase certainly at the pace that it had 2 or 3 or 4 years ago, but we're still planning to increase. It, but we will always reevaluate that. And on the technology front, there's one area within our company that we actually have a pretty disciplined approach in terms of budgeting and allocation of resources, both labor and capital. And while that is expected to increase a little bit in 2012, we're keeping pretty good tabs on that and most likely slightly increase the lower rate than the growth.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: So just to follow up, do you expect there a small amount of expenses -- expenses should decline this year than last you because of that reason?
componenttext: So just to follow up, do you expect there a small amount of expenses -- expenses should decline this year than last you because of that reason?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, that technology cost would be across all business groups, so it could also show up in commercial or agency. So it will only be direct. The only thing I would point out, at least in the first 6 months of this year, remember, and we've noted this to t
componenttext: Well, that technology cost would be across all business groups, so it could also show up in commercial or agency. So it will only be direct. The only thing I would point out, at least in the first 6 months of this year, remember, and we've noted this to the change in accounting for deferred acquisition costs, we will have, in the first 6 months, approximately $25 million of costs that are no longer deferred. Most of that shows up in the direct channel expense ratio, not all of it, but the vast majority of it will show up in the expense ratio. So earlier in the year, you might see a level that will not be the same as towards the end of the year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple questions. On Snapshot, so if I'm insured by another company, can I just call Progressive up and say I want Snapshot, and have it sent to me and become a Progressive policy holder under Snapshot right away?
componenttext: Just a couple questions. On Snapshot, so if I'm insured by another company, can I just call Progressive up and say I want Snapshot, and have it sent to me and become a Progressive policy holder under Snapshot right away?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, let me describe the way it works. What you do is you could call us up, go online, go to an agent. It seems any other way that you would do for us. You will get a quote based on all of the measures that we would use and previously have used and de
componenttext: Michael, let me describe the way it works. What you do is you could call us up, go online, go to an agent. It seems any other way that you would do for us. You will get a quote based on all of the measures that we would use and previously have used and develop a rate. Let's just say for now, $500, for the sake of argument. You would then get us, would you like to try to improve your rate through the use of Snapshot? You would say yes in this case, and we would give you a device i.e. we would give it to you in the mail, as you would follow up within a few days and you would install it in your vehicle. We would know the moment you install it. And in return, you get to be able to see exactly what data is relevant to use on our website. And after 30 days of usage, we would say, Michael, based on your driving behavior that we've observed and the things that are important to us, we think that you could be due to a 17% discount, and it's the deal we're going to equity. We'll actually give you that 17% discount for the remaining term of your policy. We write 6-month policy, and as of this stage, you've had a 30-day measurement period and probably a few days in the mail and stuff that maybe with 35 or 40 days into the policy. So we would then give you that discount for the remaining part of your policy. We would continue to observe your driving behavior through the chip that you've installed, and we would require that you keep it installed. And at the end of that policy period are actually the required number of days that we offer you a renewal price of the expiration of your policy, we would then tell you, "Hey, that 17% -- okay, that 17% looks good or we go it wasn't as good as we thought. It's really 15%, or maybe it's a little better than we thought, 21%." Now I'm not being convenient in suggesting that. The fact is it doesn't change very much, so we want people to know that it's not like we're going to give you 17% and then say 6 months so it's really 3%. We would do that if that's what it says, but that does not seem to be a behavior that the observed. So you would then get a renewal quote that would reflect the longer period of observation that we've made. At that point, we would say that unit by the way have some value to us. You're obligated to return it to us, and that would become inventory for us to recycle to the next present at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I see, okay. Fair enough. I guess on Shazam a little bit more. So the first stage of Snapshot, kind of think about I think following up to just question earlier, sort of taking premium per PIF down as you convert full fare customers, your own customers an
componenttext: I see, okay. Fair enough. I guess on Shazam a little bit more. So the first stage of Snapshot, kind of think about I think following up to just question earlier, sort of taking premium per PIF down as you convert full fare customers, your own customers and then the next stage is once you normalize for these lower zone of aggregate margins on this cohort that you're now charging a discount to, but where retention is better, I mean is that kind of how to think about the stages of profitability coming or the impact of profitability from Snapshot?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that is fair. Let me go one step further that ultimately, if we have greater insight into the true cost that individual should be paying and willing to allow those that should be paying less to pay less, yes we would have retention. But those who
componenttext:
I think that is fair. Let me go one step further that ultimately, if we have greater insight into the true cost that individual should be paying and willing to allow those that should be paying less to pay less, yes we would have retention. But those who should be paying more and are not, eventually, that would have to get recognized in the industry. Let's just assume losses on either created nor destroyed.
We're just trying to price to the individuals proportionate to they are contribution to those losses. So if, I'll say it again, if, Premium customers leave other companies and come to us, it is then likely they've been less for higher premium customers and those rates will need -- their rates will need to reflect that at some point in time. So think about this as sort of a interjecting a very new variable, which is hugely disruptive, doesn't change the losses, but it reallocates the premiums.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just one last one on the question before was direct. I think you said ad spending was up, quotes new apps and life expectancy indirect were down in '11. But then you mentioned also that in 4Q on a year-over-year basis, some of those
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just one last one on the question before was direct. I think you said ad spending was up, quotes new apps and life expectancy indirect were down in '11. But then you mentioned also that in 4Q on a year-over-year basis, some of those trends saw an inflection, saw an improvement. We can't really see that in the KRA the discussion. And can you kind of talk about that stuff period for 4Q and how these metrics change versus the trends that you show on an annual basis?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, you are correct. You're not going to see PLE measures change quickly there, quite glacial changes and that's by nature the way we measure them so on and so forth. I think I would just reiterate there, it really is the most stabilization of rate in Fl
componenttext: Yes, you are correct. You're not going to see PLE measures change quickly there, quite glacial changes and that's by nature the way we measure them so on and so forth. I think I would just reiterate there, it really is the most stabilization of rate in Florida versus the shock. But I'd love to be able to avoid at all costs is shocking our customers, our business customers, with their rate change that is let's say greater than 5%. That's a shock generally to consumers, and we did that. Would have to do that, others are doing it perhaps -- perhaps they're doing it little a even as we speak. I don't expect or can't illuminate the possibility that we have other changes that we need to make. And as we start to measure our PLE for customers that are now renewing or renewing into the new rate revisions that they've come in through, we should expect to see that policy life expectancy grow. And obviously, in the state of Florida, our average premiums will grow because we've taken rate. We also see overall a little bit of an increase in severities across the board. I don't think that's a new. Most companies are probably seeing much the same thing relatively tolerable in bodily injury and a little faster than we've seen for sometime in the physical damage and collision coverages. Frequency still tends to be a little bit on the downside. Personally, I get nervous about frequency. That can change quickly. Severity tends to be pretty reasonable and real when you see it. Gas prices might change, a few things in them next month or 2 who knows.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd add to that, at these as it relates to the direct channel, we are seeing more recently an increase in our conversion rate, and which is fueling some of the business growth. So whether that is reflective of our rates relative to other ra
componenttext: The only thing I'd add to that, at these as it relates to the direct channel, we are seeing more recently an increase in our conversion rate, and which is fueling some of the business growth. So whether that is reflective of our rates relative to other rates in the marketplace, I suspect so. I don't know all the rate changes of our forks have taken, but have you seen in the industry, combined ratios have gone up for many carriers. So I suspect it's a combination of our rates relative to others in the marketplace has improved our conversion rate a fair amount, particularly in direct. And some of the growth in both channels was -- some of it is a reflection of either rate changes we have taken or competitors rate changes, because it is not necessarily every individual states have this elevated levels there. Some states, there are some states that are growing quite nicely.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012

componenttext: Glenn, earlier you, I think qualified, clarified I should say, the agency count increased from 30,000 to 35,000 as just the revised reporting number, but not really a step increase in the number of agents? And I'm wondering whether Allstate's relationship termination was a little bit more than 1,000 agents in the fourth quarter. Is that a step change? headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012

componenttext: Yes, it does, and I recognize by answering, it might seem strange. But we just reduced 30,000 for an awful long time and a few of us were asking, if that -- should we really go back and see exactly what the number we should use? So that answer was exactly that. You're asking now is the change or other changes that are being reported from Allstate, having any effect on the channels, I would tell you to my knowledge, which is I think pretty decent, not in large enough numbers to really talk about here. But have we had agents come and asked us for appointment as independent agents to continue their professional careers, yes.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012

componenttextpreview: As a significant part of revenues?
componenttext: As a significant part of revenues?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, not really, and I don't mean to be avoiding anything there. But frankly, the revenues, this is pointing out a lot of things for us, which is all fine. But I would really encourage you as analyst to one, take me and my word, I'll take to tell you anyth
componenttext: No, not really, and I don't mean to be avoiding anything there. But frankly, the revenues, this is pointing out a lot of things for us, which is all fine. But I would really encourage you as analyst to one, take me and my word, I'll take to tell you anything that's really appropriate to tell with Australia with volume or anything like that, that this is truly, at this point, a rounding era for most of what we're talking about. Having said that, that doesn't mean it's not something that we take seriously and important. Clearly, the indications that I've often profit, not necessarily us to promote our own position but just how difficult it is to establish brand, get a flow of customers, match your advertising with your average premium, be able to be comfortable that your policy life expectancy is a measurable and reliable number. Those are critically important to a Direct business, and I can't stress how the important they are. And surprisingly, we're finding things in Australia that we found in 1992 when we started direct in United States, and they take a long time to be able to go from a standing start to something meaningful. But the premium in Australia is really less than $10 million, so -- and likely not to exceed that in great proportion this year. So we would be spending a lot of time talking about something that's not much more than valuable R&D investment for us at this point in time.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012

componenttext: Understood. Is that consistent with your expectations say 3 years ago?

componenttext: Probably a little bit slower, but I haven't found anything that is shocking we. Probably calibration, we were a little more optimistic on certain measures than is turning out to be the case. But surely, nothing that is sort of like well, how do we miss that kind of thing, not at all. And this is one where we have to have some patience.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012

componenttext: I guess two sort of follow-up questions, because a lot has been discussed. The one is, if I remember he first quarter, thing in the shareholder letter, you mentioned being virtually profitable in nearly all states. I know you've been talking about Florida a little bit here, but I was wondering if you can give us an update on that. And then to the extent you're comfortable, the trends that seem to have reached an inflection in the 4Q that you've talked about. Can you talk a bit about what you're seeing early in 2012? And maybe particularly how that relates to the ad growth in direct being slower than you would have liked last year?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, do you want to take the profitability by states? Just asked Brian sort of think issues there. We think of two different measures, one is 96 our target and two, profitability being 100 combined.
componenttext: Sure, do you want to take the profitability by states? Just asked Brian sort of think issues there. We think of two different measures, one is 96 our target and two, profitability being 100 combined.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of profitability, certainly in 2010, we acknowledged that we have some profit concerns with some of our large state and we took corrective actions, and many of those, we to we mentioned in the past, we are saved have the personal injury prot
componenttext: Yes, in terms of profitability, certainly in 2010, we acknowledged that we have some profit concerns with some of our large state and we took corrective actions, and many of those, we to we mentioned in the past, we are saved have the personal injury protection coverage versus on lost has accelerated. We took pretty significant corrective actions in all of those states where we effectively raised amounts that contributed to lower new application production in early parts of 2011. We then became much more comfortable with our rate level in these large states including Florida and New York and New Jersey. The one state where we still have some fairly significant concerns in terms of profitability, the state I would mention would be Michigan, where we still have not been able to achieve an underwriting profit. We're still -- we've taken significant corrective actions, but we assumed have ways to go there. But certainly, in the area, we've taken lots of great data and new business production has fallen off as a result. The other state that had been of mentioned previously was Massachusetts. we are pleased to report that, that is getting, in 2011, was very close to being profitable on a calendar year basis for the year, and we feel good about our rate level there. And look to be able to see that state growing again. Having said all that, I would say we always need to stay vigilant in some of these highly volatile states, Florida being one of them New York being another. Michigan will always be in our watch and monitoring list. The loss trends and the environments tend to be very volatile, and we've seen this not only over the last 3 years, but if you go back 10 years or 15 years, these tend to be very volatile markets where combined ratios for us in the industry have come up and down corrective actions. And so we need to sort of remain vigilant there. As Glenn talked about earlier in his conversation, it's one thing to be growing. It's another thing to be profitable, but how do we compare both profitable growth, it's yet to -- we're dealing diligently on that. So we feel good about our aggregate rate level. In last year, our rate changes has been relatively modest across the marketplace. Rate change in the last 12 months is something like plus 1% and in aggregate, but I'm certain there will be individual states where we'll have to take more corrective actions, but that's part of our discipline and what we're trying to do each and everyday.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2012
componenttextpreview: And, Allison, trends in the fourth quarter, I'm not sure exactly what you're looking for there, but that we give a couple pieces of color. I mentioned earlier that physical damage, severity trends are now a little faster than we've seen for sometime, whic
componenttext: And, Allison, trends in the fourth quarter, I'm not sure exactly what you're looking for there, but that we give a couple pieces of color. I mentioned earlier that physical damage, severity trends are now a little faster than we've seen for sometime, which is okay. We priced to those a we're not so ridiculous that don't necessarily cost consumers to have major problems, but we're starting to see all of pickup in new car sales. And all of that could be good for our perspective. The bodily injury, that's the physical damage as you well know is not a big driver of reserves, so I'm not too worried about that. We just need to make sure that we need to get into pricing at a price level. Bodily injury, which could be easily big driver of reserves and pricing seems to be manageable. The one that Brian hit with almost all states to be mentioned, one that really is always going to be something on top of mind for all carriers and auto is PIP. PIP sometimes and severities that we can sit and talk about and then the real question is why is this happening? And unfortunately, that answer gets a little trickier. In Florida, there is some very real issues in terms of why that is happening right now because of some changes in quote decisions that have promoted a large number of claims that we believe reconcile our sold and paid to be reconsidered. And that is something that the whole industry is facing. That's not a trend that you typically can anticipate or put into your pricing. So I hope you don't see a lot of that. This year, gas prices might affect a little bit the monitor or the mileage driven. One of the comments that we made in our investor meeting is for us, this is actually trying to be alert to those frequency changes, possibly driven by exogenous events such as gas prices. We now have a very large sample of automobiles running around the United States that we can actually determine, if, in fact, there are instantaneous changes in miles driven based on certain events or at least to try to relate those as quickly as possible. So we feel great that we're in a position to have that early monitoring device such as the Snapshot devices that we have out there. We still see a fair amount of advertising in the industry. I don't expect that to falloff, but it's my belief, it becomes harder and harder for those without a great deal of brand recognition to break into the significant consideration sets, so we're delighted that where there. And we're going to price, as true in the chart of industry wide premium growth and combined ratio. And you will remember when the industry was running at low 90s and hitting 80s on a regular basis, those days of long since changed. And now that when I recognize everybody has their own goal, I suspect most companies are a lot closer to their acceptable level of combined ratio, and some possibly over it. The game gets a lot harder now. The tight road is really there, and a few points one way or another is not absorbed by the slack in the combined ratio. And that's likely to be overall a driver of premium growth, and most of this conversation to date has been us talking a little bit about what I think will be a meaningful offset to that overall premium growth driver for our customers and in their ability to at least -- or our new customers to offset that with the driving behavior discounts.

componenttext: A large part of that favorable development, and in fact, the large part of our overall development was settlements and larger losses. So think of it as higher limits policies. And those actually have a tendency to take longer to settle. So it's really closures and some of those older grades that less than reserves amounts, which is why they're showing up in '08 and '09 sort of accident years.
