And that really relates to PIP and we talked a little bit about that in June. So actually, on a current rate level and in the marketplace, we actually feel pretty good about our current rate and what we're writing today is it adequate levels. We actually took a modest rate increase in the past couple of months. But we actually think on a going-forward basis, our rate accuracy in Florida is positioned. the -- we still have the remaining exposure on the PIP development and we'll see how that plays out. But we actually feel pretty comfortable in our current level. And the most important thing is how is the current accident period results and we're doing okay about that.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would say it has deteriorated from last year, but it is really more specific to the agency channel as opposed to the direct channel. We feel very comfortable at rate level and profitability in the direct channel. The agency channel, on the other hand, i
componenttext: I would say it has deteriorated from last year, but it is really more specific to the agency channel as opposed to the direct channel. We feel very comfortable at rate level and profitability in the direct channel. The agency channel, on the other hand, is not meeting profit targets. A couple of years ago, we lowered rates a fair amount and we made a little bit too far. We've taken a small increase. We'll likely need additional rate. And in the short term, we are doing other things that we can to reduce new business writings. But direct channel, which is a bigger channel for us actually in California, we feel very good about that. It's more than an issue on the agency channel.

componenttext: The thing for us is where we value in some products in the short to intermediate part of the curve, we'll add. We're not trying to hit the yield in our management of natural total return. And our view at the moment is that risk maybe not near term, but eventually if having a longer duration with rates as low as they are, this leads us a bit vulnerable, so that's not a risk we're willing to take at the moment.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: Excellent. And my follow-up today is a little bit on the severity. In the PIP in Florida in particular, the last time we had a transfer problem, it was very much a fraud issue. Is there a case again this time because sometimes, it's about policy terms, sometimes it's about issues that have to do with the way the structure benefits are given. If we've been able to kind of home in on what really cost the transfer issue this time around?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: This is a different type of issue, Brian. You're somewhat closer. Do you want to sort of give a synopsis of what it's happened in Florida subsequently?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. We won't go into a lot of detail because some of it involves litigation, and so I'm not going to comment on all that. Suffice it to say, the unfavorable development, which is driving sort of core transfer results and including calendar year results,
componenttext: Yes. We won't go into a lot of detail because some of it involves litigation, and so I'm not going to comment on all that. Suffice it to say, the unfavorable development, which is driving sort of core transfer results and including calendar year results, relates to previously closed things, things that we have previously closed where some court rulings would suggest that we did not pay now. Now we believe we did and we believe we paid relative to our contract, and it's an issue in terms of the course, in terms of actual contract wording, which is more specifically what the issue is about. So as a result of that, we have had to reopen some claims from previous accident years, and that's causing the unfavorable development. We won't comment a lot more because it involves some litigation, but that is what is. Now, whether the question is, is there fraud, et cetera in Florida and has that changed all the time, I think it goes in ways. But on specific unfavorable development, I wouldn't pinpoint specifically the fraud. This is more contractual wording and litigation issue.

componenttext: We believe it's widespread. It's always hard to know exactly what everybody else has in contract. issue gets a lot more complex, so you see we're sort of hedging a little, not for lack of wanting to disclose because there are issues that doesn't make sense to talk a great deal about right now. But the real issue to your question, what's the driver of severity, this one's  a pretty weird one and unusual. Its claims that we believe were closed and settled appropriately and now coming back to us, and in some cases, getting additional payment on those claims, driving an increase in severity.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Josh Stirling with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question is from Josh Stirling with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I'd love to talk more about the sort of the severity rolled forward in pricing actions, and maybe just start up start with clarify something. I think, Brian, you raised this, this morning I think it helps illustrate something that our investors are con
componenttext: So I'd love to talk more about the sort of the severity rolled forward in pricing actions, and maybe just start up start with clarify something. I think, Brian, you raised this, this morning I think it helps illustrate something that our investors are confused around, which is with the headline 6% severity number, whether that's a reasonable proxy for projecting future severity? Or whether we ought to be using the paid severity measures or what the implied severity change was for accident year 2011 that you guys have effectively disclosed? And in line with that, I think the question that is, what is that as you sort of a go-forward view severity that's reasonable and not distorted by reserve changes, what is that -- what on a pure premium basis does this look like that you guys actually need in terms of rate? And if you simplistically do this, you'll add up 6% times the larger numbers for positive frequency changes. And you say that you guys rate changes are well below the rate need that actually -- sort of simplistic loss trend that you've seeing.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's a lot there, Josh. I would try to at least take pieces. And Glenn, feel free or Al, feel free to chime in. The best measure for severity, I believe over time, is your own assessment of accident year severity change year-over-year. Unfortunately at
componenttext: There's a lot there, Josh. I would try to at least take pieces. And Glenn, feel free or Al, feel free to chime in. The best measure for severity, I believe over time, is your own assessment of accident year severity change year-over-year. Unfortunately at any given point in time, you don't know what that is because they developed over time. So that's why we record both incurred. And I want to let people know that the paid is slightly lower. Now paid can be influenced by a lot of things, your closure rate, how you're closing more simple claims earlier or later versus previous years. So there are pitfalls and all of those. The other thing, suffice it to say, that we believe severity have increased versus what we had seen particularly in the previous couple of years where our severities for bodily injury coverage and so the other coverages had been fairly modest, low-single digits, low-single digits. And in fact, last year, we would have said 2011 end of last year, we thought bodily injuries severities were relatively flat. And we found out that as things have developed that we are little bit short in that, end that's how we unfavorable reserve development. So we increase our severity estimates for 2011 accident year about 2% from where we thought at the end of the year. As we project future severities, that's a select. If we had a crystal ball to our future severities are, we -- it would be great. We have increased our select for future severities. I would not go all the way up to the 6% incurred severity that we are recording right now. The other thing I would just say relative to frequency, for certain, we have started to increase frequency. In bodily injury, we've seen it for the past couple of quarters. Property damage and PIP us more second quarter related. was 1% in the second quarter. Frequencies now in 2012 are comparable to what they were in 2010 or 2 years ago. Last year, we have negative decreases in frequency. So it's not as if frequency is way out of control. They are now closer to what they were 2 years ago. And some of the things last year that may have affected frequency were gas prices and the like. The reality of it is for us and industry in the first quarter, collision frequency was down significantly. Actually, i was down like 10% in the first quarter. I think something like 5% for the industry. And that clearly, I believe, is attributable to very mild weather in Northeast Midwest and sort of onetime event, but nothing that will be expected long term. So on frequency front, I would say our frequencies are comparable to a couple of years ago, so not overly concerned about that. One that we will continue to watch more as BI frequency going up a little bit faster. And then on the severity front, we've increased future selects but to project and say, Hey, we think the number is 6, I think that will be on the high end. They will be less than that.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hey, that's really helpful, really helpful color. The other question that I'd love to just clarify is relating to sort of pricing actions. It sounds like that earlier, you said that what have been sort of 5% by fall sounds like it may be a couple of point
componenttext: Hey, that's really helpful, really helpful color. The other question that I'd love to just clarify is relating to sort of pricing actions. It sounds like that earlier, you said that what have been sort of 5% by fall sounds like it may be a couple of points more of rate by year end. I make sure I understood it correctly. And then just generally, I'd love to understand how much your recent rate filings, what rate does what average rate increase you've been asking for? And then if you can expand a little bit on that, if we sort of model out against future trends, how much revenues and sort of an offset to that should we be expecting from nationally, your monthly transactions, which I think Glenn is referencing?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of average rate change, think of more in the sort of mid-single digit rate changes. That's not that -- they're not all there, but think of it as more in that range. So at it relates to what percentage of the country we coverage to get this 2% or
componenttext: In terms of average rate change, think of more in the sort of mid-single digit rate changes. That's not that -- they're not all there, but think of it as more in that range. So at it relates to what percentage of the country we coverage to get this 2% or 3% that we've taken in last couple of months, most of rate changes are most mid-single digits and that is more our preferred approach. We don't want to get into positions where we have to take plus 10s because that will definitely adversely affect retention rates and the like. So our preferred approach is to take consistent amount of rate changes. So think of the average rate changes in the mid-single digits for most states we've taken rate changes. And in terms of the monthly rate factor, it is not a significant amount of the rate change taken but it is an increasing portion, because I think some of the experience says proved and methodology of taking rate over time. So we've implemented a few more states and some states increased that percentage. But in terms of the overall rate change, I would not assume that is a big portion of the 5% rate change through current period or 7 at the end of the year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your understanding of the price statement, how much was taken and how much we're planning to take is correct. Only other point I would suggest to those who  somewhat close to it, most of the changes we're taking now, most are bases rate changes. And the r
componenttext: Your understanding of the price statement, how much was taken and how much we're planning to take is correct. Only other point I would suggest to those who  somewhat close to it, most of the changes we're taking now, most are bases rate changes. And the reason I point out is sometimes you can take rate changes. And if it's so on and so forth, that may or may not flow through in market based on the mix that you attained. The -- Perhaps the more definitive way to get the rate is to take it at base rate level. We're quite comfortable of the design of that product, so most of these changes are base rate changes and would expect them to flow through, somewhat close to the amount that we taken.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: Just wanted to shift gears and maybe get a quick tutorial on the gain sharing metrics. And I mean, specifically how does it react to our combined ratio above the target like you're currently producing? And then also, are you -- are there any tweaks that need to be made? Are you effectively getting the right behavior but the wrong profitability? So is it over-rewarding top line at the expense of profitability or anything like that?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Most of the designed areas is Brian's, so I think you can talk a little bit about the. But also comments on individual month changes and also hosted aggregate for the year, which while we're not happy with the last several points of trajectory, still is w
componenttext: Most of the designed areas is Brian's, so I think you can talk a little bit about the. But also comments on individual month changes and also hosted aggregate for the year, which while we're not happy with the last several points of trajectory, still is within target.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, as it relates to the first question about how does it react to combined ratios over target and keep in mind, as I've mentioned before, the gain share that you see is an aggregate of 5 component pieces. So there's 2 for auto and 1 for each of agency a
componenttext: Yes, as it relates to the first question about how does it react to combined ratios over target and keep in mind, as I've mentioned before, the gain share that you see is an aggregate of 5 component pieces. So there's 2 for auto and 1 for each of agency auto, specialized and commercial Auto. And as they're constructed, they are constructed relative to growth and profit trade-offs. And all of the matrices have a pretty penalty function for being over targets, and the function gets greater as a get further and further over targets. So it's slightly over target, there is a function. But as you get further and further away from target, the function is pretty severe. So I think those in particular who have the responsibility of setting prices and ensuring rate adequacy are cognizant of that. And it's one of the drivers of what you saw in June the numbers come down fairly significantly from, I believe it is 1 4 2 at the end of May and moved down to 1.29 at the end of June, and that combined ratio of 101 won't -- doesn't sit well in any matrics. So that was the primary driver of it going down, and Yes, the functions of being over target pretty severe, particularly as you to go further and further over targets. we do try and reward growth because we do want to grow, but only we want to grow after targets.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: And it doesn't sound like there's any change to the matrics or anything as part of what's happening? It is what it is, and organization will respond.
componenttext: And it doesn't sound like there's any change to the matrics or anything as part of what's happening? It is what it is, and organization will respond.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. We set these matrices actually before right of the beginning of the year. We don't change the matrices during the course of the year. And obviously over time and over the years, we do tweak on them, amend for the next year. But the matrices that we s
componenttext: Yes. We set these matrices actually before right of the beginning of the year. We don't change the matrices during the course of the year. And obviously over time and over the years, we do tweak on them, amend for the next year. But the matrices that we set at the beginning of the year, they are in force for the full year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: Okay. And then again as it relates to this, so if I was sitting in, I don't know, a theoretical state that was earning 100 combined, what would prevent me from just shutting off my advertising spend for the rest of the year and bringing my combined immediately down?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: What would prevent you is some degree of management oversight, if anything. But we try to impress our product managers with a great deal of responsibility. Recognize a large portion of our advertising is not done on a local basis. I would actually expect
componenttext: What would prevent you is some degree of management oversight, if anything. But we try to impress our product managers with a great deal of responsibility. Recognize a large portion of our advertising is not done on a local basis. I would actually expect in some certain cases that we actually temper our local advertising. That would be an action I would expect of product manager if they would running at 100. And you know the story of how we match advertising to yield, so frankly, I would expect that on an analytical level. But again, big chunk of our advertising is done on a national level. And while we will likely temper that to some degree, we are not so driven to doing action today that we'll mortgage the company going forward. We're currently operating, back to share issue, the score of 7% or a 95 9 produces the score you know that. it's a direct that's not meeting our expectations, and we'll do everything to adjust that. But also try to make sure that we're continuing to get the rate level in as responsible way, so that we can continue our growth and push for a very healthy 13, [ph] which may very well enter with the average written premium largely across the board in both channel in many states. So the short answer to the question is, as a product manager, you could do that technically. But with management oversight, we're not looking to do. That's not what we do and more importantly, a lot of it is done on a national level.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: The agency versus direct?
componenttext: The agency versus direct?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're strengthening rates more in agency than in direct. There is no big, big story there but it does look, just 2 books of business running. We try to treat them with separate indications. We're big enough in both channels and most states to be able to d
componenttext: We're strengthening rates more in agency than in direct. There is no big, big story there but it does look, just 2 books of business running. We try to treat them with separate indications. We're big enough in both channels and most states to be able to do that. And for no particular reason, other than just the way the data comes out, we're strengthening rates a little more in agency than direct at this time.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from James Engle with John W Bristol.
componenttext: Our next question is from James Engle with John W Bristol.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: Have one question, which is regarding your applications, and why is the growth faster in agency versus direct?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually it's been good. But unfortunately, my last statement might be a little bit a telling statement that we need to strengthen rates a little bit more in agency than direct. So you should take from that, agents are very responsive to us. They lik
componenttext: Yes, actually it's been good. But unfortunately, my last statement might be a little bit a telling statement that we need to strengthen rates a little bit more in agency than direct. So you should take from that, agents are very responsive to us. They like our product and they like our rate degree deals. But we've going to have to take that up and as I've said in many occasions, agents are facilitated by software that gives them very good market comparisons from lots of different companies. So while we've being very attractive, we're going to take our rates up. It's even hard for me to answer the question. I just have to wait and see what that means. In an individual situation, every agency has different level of carry different numbers of carriers, different combinations of carriers. I would expect that competitive mix to go down just because that's sort of a pretty clear statement. You take rates up, your competitive goes down. What I can't really know is how to calibrate that even in a constant situation, if no one takes rate changes and secondarily, if I would take rate changes. So really, I take this track in a number for the rest of the year. We are very, very happy with our year-to-date average yield and production, and we hope that certainly stays. I don't think it will stay at the current level.

componenttextpreview: Yes. On the direct side, I'd say the application count, certainly through the first 6 months of the year, relatively low growth. It's not certainly as pronounced as in agency and more of it is really to conversion gains as opposed to prospect gains. And c
componenttext: Yes. On the direct side, I'd say the application count, certainly through the first 6 months of the year, relatively low growth. It's not certainly as pronounced as in agency and more of it is really to conversion gains as opposed to prospect gains. And certainly, the change in rates will likely conversion. So going forward, we'll see how that plays out. But I would say in direct channel, most of the gains that we have so far this year more conversion related as opposed to more generational prospects.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just one other thought on agency piece, and it's still a small piece I don't want overplay this, but we did tell you at the Investor Relations meeting that we are putting a push and getting more of our message, more of our agents to understand what Snapsh
componenttext: Just one other thought on agency piece, and it's still a small piece I don't want overplay this, but we did tell you at the Investor Relations meeting that we are putting a push and getting more of our message, more of our agents to understand what Snapshot might be able to do for them. That work continues. There are some favorable results from that. We want to be the more favorable. And the reason I bring it up is it's a very interesting way to be able to also accommodate customers' desire for lower rates. In rate rising environment, may actually get people a little bit more incentive to say, Yes, maybe I'll try this because this gives me an opportunity to tell you I'm a good driver and get a lower rate. So hopefully, Snapshot is a nice time to have or it's nice time to have Snapshot in the rate rising environment.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to follow-up on Greg's question on additional tools to adjust to the elevated combined ratios. Most of the conference call has been focused on rate as your 1, 2 and 3 strategy to deal with it. With Greg, you mentioned Greg, that you suggested adver
componenttext: I want to follow-up on Greg's question on additional tools to adjust to the elevated combined ratios. Most of the conference call has been focused on rate as your 1, 2 and 3 strategy to deal with it. With Greg, you mentioned Greg, that you suggested advertising might be another tool. I was wondering if slowing down Snapshot, because of the elevated first year combined ratios of that business, might be another strategy? Or there will be other things that you would highlight as beyond price?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: We've got a couple of them, . Also mention indirectly in California agency, which is not the only place we would do this, but bill plans. So we can certainly control sometimes the flow of new business just by the attractiveness of bill plans and different
componenttext: We've got a couple of them, . Also mention indirectly in California agency, which is not the only place we would do this, but bill plans. So we can certainly control sometimes the flow of new business just by the attractiveness of bill plans and different classes of business or more than others. It's something we will do. And within Snapshot, clearly, we have a discount structure that we're very comfortable with. But if that proved, it would prove to be a little more aggressive, we have an opportunity to adjust the discount structure there. And we're not talking 1 point, 0.5 point, not move away in any way, shape or form from our excitement around Snapshot. Snapshot is something that we think actually offers consumer a way to really manage their price and this is a good thing to do that. So no, we are not planning on pulling back on Snapshot of all. But at $1 billion, which is a number that we put out in the Investor Relations meeting, we expect Snapshot to perform. And when we say perform, so fill along explanation here, it does mean that we understand new business can still meet our target, but numerically be above 96. And if that were the driver of the only reason we're above 96 today, I'd be telling you more about it. That's not a big issue, but we're not afraid of bringing on new business at greater than 96. It's the blend that we're looking for, and we see no reason to slow down any attempts to incent people to come to Progressive.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, just a great answer. Just a follow-up. You're 100% sure that it's -- the problem center being around running severity as opposed to adverse selection or any other sort of problem with the book?
componenttext: Okay, just a great answer. Just a follow-up. You're 100% sure that it's -- the problem center being around running severity as opposed to adverse selection or any other sort of problem with the book?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, 100% so it's a great certainty. But I've seen it a few times in my career as has Brian as has John on and so forth, I'm not that -- you never want to come across cocky, but I think we know how to handle this one. And while we give answers here that a
componenttext: Yes, 100% so it's a great certainty. But I've seen it a few times in my career as has Brian as has John on and so forth, I'm not that -- you never want to come across cocky, but I think we know how to handle this one. And while we give answers here that are meant to be full disclosure, the detail that goes into our rate revision is far more intense than we can get into in this type of setting, whether that be some of our commercial segments or whether it be in individual states or product designs. We do have more aggressive work on pre-binding verification in certain states where we realize there are some opportunities to be presented with individuals who are not buying the product for the intended purpose. So what I'm saying is you might have said. I think we're on top on all of things. But those are not new. Those are the things that we do all the time and we're continuing to refine them. What we see is the instantaneous sort of action. I would tell you we are very highly confident that we could fix that with the rate changes that in many cases we've already taken.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: Our next question is from Meyer Shields with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Glenn, in past, you talked about how when there's sort of turmoil in insurance marketplace, it ultimately benefits Progressive because you get rates faster than the competition. Do have that sort of expectation this time around as well?
componenttext: Glenn, in past, you talked about how when there's sort of turmoil in insurance marketplace, it ultimately benefits Progressive because you get rates faster than the competition. Do have that sort of expectation this time around as well?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm always an optimist to some degree. You might not get that from our writing at times. But the one thing that I've learned in this business is, get your rate right first and then attack the marketplace. And when you don't have your rate correct, you own
componenttext: I'm always an optimist to some degree. You might not get that from our writing at times. But the one thing that I've learned in this business is, get your rate right first and then attack the marketplace. And when you don't have your rate correct, you own up to it right away and get it correctly -- get it correct. So, yes. I mean in general, you can sort of any take of time series and you'll see that when the market is a little disrupted and rate increases, our disruption to the marketplace and go back almost close to 5 years. We really haven't seen a rate rising environment in auto insurance for a while. So I don't look at this instantaneously. We have a job to do. We know how to do it. We're confident we can get that done. We'll come out of this with higher average premiums, which is something we haven't had for a good long time. And I think there will be some market disruption and we'll go into that more tools than we've ever had before, whether it's name your price or the Snapshot. And so actually feel good about looking forward to '13 and '14.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Prior yield development, actually the last couple of actually pretty modest. So certainly in the quarter, we had about $23 million of unfavorable development. Most of that is in April. May and June have been pretty modest. What to expect for the rest of t
componenttext: Prior yield development, actually the last couple of actually pretty modest. So certainly in the quarter, we had about $23 million of unfavorable development. Most of that is in April. May and June have been pretty modest. What to expect for the rest of the year? Can't forecast or predict but generally speaking, we have generally historically see more development on the first half of the year versus the second half. It just make sense as we get further and further away from the previous years, more have have settled, et cetera. So I don't want to suggest that we won't see any more unfavorable development. There may be, but you see each month in the last 2 months, it's been much more modest than what we saw for the first 4 months. The actuarial changes actually from a reserve actuarial perspective, which we look at by segment by segment, state by state and we have a schedule for that, we are almost all the large segment are reviewed at least quarterly. We have at least last month in June, took more significant increase than we have recently. And we'll continue to do our actuarial review and make some adjustments as we see them or need them.

componenttext: Nothing notable, Ian. New business carries of it in elevated frequency, but that's not new. That's not unexpected. There really isn't anything. headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012

componenttext: Okay., great. And if I can ask 1 Snapshot question. What happens -- so just the idea of actually on trial and after that, your discounts lock in. How do you account for things like lifestyle changes, right? Maybe when someone does the trial, they're taking the train tour because they're only driving on the weekends. And a year from now, they got a new job where they're driving 45 minutes in rush hour traffic each way every day. And their profile has changed, but you don't know it because the device is not current anymore.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's no question, those types of risks are in the design. Just period, they are. We also reserve the right and will likely use the right to re-sample. So even though Snapshot is a discrete measurement period, we are actively looking for our progra
componenttext: Yes. There's no question, those types of risks are in the design. Just period, they are. We also reserve the right and will likely use the right to re-sample. So even though Snapshot is a discrete measurement period, we are actively looking for our programs as to when and how to be alluded to re-measuring and resampling. So it is no question that is a lot of design positives to being able to do the discrete measurement period, lots of positives there. There are also asking negatives and there's no question that you might capture somebody at the point where their behavior is not particularly representative of their ongoing behavior. We are very cognizant of that. We don't think that, that is large enough a percentage to be overly concerned with, but we will be concerned to the extent of resampling. Now obviously people bring on to their policy during a point in time, and that's certainly something we will likely for them.

componenttextpreview: Yes. We find 100 new ways to beat ourselves up on things like these. But on the severity side, that is pretty tricky. I mean, unfortunately, we had to get the date that. whether we like it are not, be kind of drive looking out the rearview mirror. It has
componenttext: Yes. We find 100 new ways to beat ourselves up on things like these. But on the severity side, that is pretty tricky. I mean, unfortunately, we had to get the date that. whether we like it are not, be kind of drive looking out the rearview mirror. It has to happen and that's -- we don't have the way to sort of create index of health care costs and this would be directly effective. The one that I think that is maybe retrospect, we could have, should have, all other words that go along with that is while frequency have been declining almost monotonically for the decade, 11 declining didn't look aberration. But now it looks somewhat ever and then maybe there's more a little more frequency plateau around the level of 2010. And that one, we'll have to see. I mean, next year, we might be talking about having to down again the safety kind of costs, sort of the things that happening to the technology of vehicles. They're all in roads. They're all driving that frequency. So frequency as a long-term monotonically adoption is a good bet, but we probably overacted or trusted the 11 more than we might have, should have.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: So just one quick follow-up on Florida PIP. So just simplistically, you don't think you made a mistake growing there or much is the bad court decision? Is that gist I should take away?
componenttext: So just one quick follow-up on Florida PIP. So just simplistically, you don't think you made a mistake growing there or much is the bad court decision? Is that gist I should take away?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, no. Florida is a terrific state for us. Florida PIP is, I'm sure I shared the sentiment with many in the business. PIP is awfully difficult coverage there. Sometimes you don't know if you're coming or going. We paid claims that we believe were paid.
componenttext: Yes, no. Florida is a terrific state for us. Florida PIP is, I'm sure I shared the sentiment with many in the business. PIP is awfully difficult coverage there. Sometimes you don't know if you're coming or going. We paid claims that we believe were paid. And when I say we believe we paid, I'm not sort of being an insurance company here. I think the reasonable person would believe they were paid fair and accurately. And now we're having to reopen them. Now that's a very, very unusual circumstance to pay more. So that doesn't reflect on our feeling about Florida in any way, shape or form. We'll get this one behind us. PIP reform has taken place in Florida. None of us know exactly what that's going to mean, but at least we have a little more clarity going forward. But I guess we have only a period of ambiguity that we're working through right now. But no, Florida is a great state of that for us, but for the most part, not a problem. PIP can be problematic.

Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. This conference call is also available via an audio webcast. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. The company will not make detailed comments in addition to those provided in its quarterly report on Form 10-Q and letter to shareholders, which have been posted to the company's website and will use this conference call to respond to questions. 
Acting as moderator for the call will be Matt Downing. At this time, I will turn the call over to Mr. Downing.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Wendy, and good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; and Brian Domeck, our CFO; and Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. This call is scheduled to last about an hour.
componenttext:
Thank you, Wendy, and good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; and Brian Domeck, our CFO; and Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. This call is scheduled to last about an hour. 
As always, our discussions on this call may include forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to many risks and uncertainties that could cause the actual events and results to differ materially from those discussed during this call. Additional information concerning those risks and uncertainties is available in our 2010 annual report on Form 10-K and our quarterly report on Form 10-Q issued during 2012, where you will find discussions of the risk factors affecting our businesses, Safe Harbor statements relating to forward-looking statements and other discussions of the risks, uncertainties and other challenges we face. Each of these documents can be found via the Investors page of our website, progressive.com. 
Wendy, we are now ready to take our first question.

componenttext: Okay. That's good news. And then just for the second, a follow-up.
