headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Keith Walsh with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is from Keith Walsh with Citi.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. How much of the 6% projection for severity would be related to what you're seeing in Florida PIP?
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. How much of the 6% projection for severity would be related to what you're seeing in Florida PIP?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's mostly the BI. You want to talk about Florida?
componenttext: That's mostly the BI. You want to talk about Florida?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: The severity that we're referring to was -- on the 6% was more on the BI side. PIP severity has increased as well. I don't have that here in the -- but I guess the PIP severity also is actually above 6% so far through the first 6 months. But PIP, in parti
componenttext: The severity that we're referring to was -- on the 6% was more on the BI side. PIP severity has increased as well. I don't have that here in the -- but I guess the PIP severity also is actually above 6% so far through the first 6 months. But PIP, in particular, you have to look at on a state-by-state basis where Florida is actually a higher than average PIP severity, some of that obviously driven by the unfavorable development. So PIP severity, on an incurred basis, is higher than 6% so far this year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any other states are causing issues besides Florida?
componenttext: Okay. And any other states are causing issues besides Florida?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Relative to PIP, I would say Florida is the main driver. Michigan, which is historically been problematic for us, is getting better. I wouldn't say we're necessarily all the way there, but we're certainly in a much better position there than we have done
componenttext: Relative to PIP, I would say Florida is the main driver. Michigan, which is historically been problematic for us, is getting better. I wouldn't say we're necessarily all the way there, but we're certainly in a much better position there than we have done in a long time.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just for Glenn, you mentioned you were I guess maybe disappointed at the timing it took to recognize the loss cost. I guess in hindsight, is there anything you could have done or any other information you had that should have maybe
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just for Glenn, you mentioned you were I guess maybe disappointed at the timing it took to recognize the loss cost. I guess in hindsight, is there anything you could have done or any other information you had that should have maybe caused you to react more quickly, recognizing this is in hindsight, of course?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. We find hundreds of ways to beat ourselves up on things like this. But on the severity side, that was pretty tricky. I mean, unfortunately, we have to get the data and see it. And whether we like it or not, we kind of drive looking out the rear-visio
componenttext: Yes. We find hundreds of ways to beat ourselves up on things like this. But on the severity side, that was pretty tricky. I mean, unfortunately, we have to get the data and see it. And whether we like it or not, we kind of drive looking out the rear-vision mirror. It has to have happened, and that's -- we just don't have a way to sort of take a great index of health care cost and say this will be directly effective. The one that I think that maybe, in retrospect, we could have, should have, all the other words that would go along with that is that while frequency had been declining almost monotonically for the entire decade, 11 declining didn't look aberrant. But now it looks somewhat aberrant, and maybe there's a bit more of a frequency plateau around the levels of 2010. And that one, we'll have to see. I mean, next year, we might be talking about it having gone down again, the safety kind of influences in cars. You know the sort of the things that are happening to the technology of vehicles. They're all inroads. They're all driving that frequency. So frequency, as a long-term monotonic reduction, is a fairly good bet, but we probably overreacted or trusted the 11 more than we might have and should have.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: So just one quick follow-up on Florida PIP. So if I'm just -- simplistically, you don't think you made a mistake growing there? Or it was just more bad court decisions? Is that gist I should take away?
componenttext: So just one quick follow-up on Florida PIP. So if I'm just -- simplistically, you don't think you made a mistake growing there? Or it was just more bad court decisions? Is that gist I should take away?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Florida is a terrific state for us. Florida PIP -- and I'd share -- and I'm sure I share this sentiment with many others in the business. PIP is just an awfully difficult coverage there. Sometimes, you don't know if you're coming or going. We pai
componenttext: Yes. No, Florida is a terrific state for us. Florida PIP -- and I'd share -- and I'm sure I share this sentiment with many others in the business. PIP is just an awfully difficult coverage there. Sometimes, you don't know if you're coming or going. We paid claims that we believe were paid. And when I say we believe we paid, I'm not sort of being an insurance company here. I think a reasonable person would believe they were paid fair and accurately. And now, we're having to reopen them. That's a very, very unusual circumstance and pay more. So that doesn't reflect on our feelings about Florida in any way, shape or form. We'll get this one behind us. PIP reform has taken place in Florida. None of us know exactly what that's going to mean. But at least, we have a little more clarity going forward, though we definitely have a period of ambiguity that we're working through right now. But no, Florida's a great state for us and for the most part, not a problem. PIP can be problematic.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012

componenttext:
Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. This conference call is also available via an audio webcast. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. The company will not make detailed comments in addition to those provided in its quarterly report on Form 10-Q and Letter to Shareholders, which have been posted to the company's website and will use this conference call to respond to questions.
Acting as moderator for the call will be Matt Downing. At this time, I will turn the call over to Mr. Downing.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating in today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; Brian Domeck, our CFO. Also in the line is Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. The call is scheduled to last about an hour.As alwa
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating in today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; Brian Domeck, our CFO. Also in the line is Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. The call is scheduled to last about an hour.
As always, our discussions on this call may include forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to many risks and uncertainties that could cause the actual events and results to differ materially from those discussed during this call. Additional information concerning those risks and uncertainties is available in our 2011 annual report on Form 10-K and our quarterly report on Form 10-Q issued during 2012, where you will find discussions of the risk factors affecting our businesses, Safe Harbor statements relating to forward-looking statements and other discussions of the risks, uncertainties and other challenges we face. Each of these documents can be found via the Investors page of our website, progressive.com.
Lenny, we are now ready to take our first question.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Michael Zaremski with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Michael Zaremski with Credit Suisse.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I was curious. So with rate increases matching the rise in severity but seemingly above the combined loss cost trend of the frequency plus severity. Would your target be the drive margin significantly below 96 to provide a cushion for future loss cost
componenttext: So I was curious. So with rate increases matching the rise in severity but seemingly above the combined loss cost trend of the frequency plus severity. Would your target be the drive margin significantly below 96 to provide a cushion for future loss cost pikes? Or is it to get back to 96 in order to begin growing PIF again?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: More the latter, 96. We never sold perfect on all of that targeting nor do we know exactly what future trends will be. But I think we can just quickly recap through the year, let's just focus on auto, taken about a 6 points of rate, give or take. A little
componenttext: More the latter, 96. We never sold perfect on all of that targeting nor do we know exactly what future trends will be. But I think we can just quickly recap through the year, let's just focus on auto, taken about a 6 points of rate, give or take. A little bit differently, Agency, Direct, but that's reasonably close. Second quarter, I think we explained carefully that we could a little bit behind on timing. So we've taken some additional rate during the second and third quarter. And as I said of my letter, I think we will that's matching that now. We will continue, that's not a one-time issue, so we will continue to take trend and do our normal rate revision processes. So rate revision processes are completely dynamic, happen all the time. What really happened in the second and third quarter, which is a little bit of a catch-up for, perhaps, some trend that we may have gotten just little behind on but our targets remain at 96. And as I said in the latter, we are thankful for the inflationary premium growth, which is certainly apparent. Would've to get unit growth and that's what we seek. We seek the combination of growing and good margins. So continue to try to think about us as a company that's going to grow the opportunity and it's our target margins a target margins come first.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a final follow-up, the expense ratio seems to be tracking recently below historical trend. Can you talk about the drivers there and how long these levels could persist if at all?
componenttext: Okay. And as a final follow-up, the expense ratio seems to be tracking recently below historical trend. Can you talk about the drivers there and how long these levels could persist if at all?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian.
componenttext: Yes, Brian.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: You're right that the expense ratio in the third quarter, in particular, in the last several months has been a little bit lower. A big component piece is in the third quarter, we consciously decided reduce a little bit of our advertising spend relatively
componenttext: You're right that the expense ratio in the third quarter, in particular, in the last several months has been a little bit lower. A big component piece is in the third quarter, we consciously decided reduce a little bit of our advertising spend relatively to certainly what we had coming into the year and actually under the lower rate than last year at this time. So some of that is contributing to the lower expense ratio and you could see that more obviously in the Direct channel expense ratio versus the Agency. And then the other component piece is just with the earned premium growth with higher levels that we've experience for number of years we are getting some leverage on the higher earned premium related to some salary cost and other fixed expenses in the organization. But it's a combination of the lower advertising spend less higher earned premium growth rate that's really driving it.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: So that lower ad spend I believe that Investor Day, you alluded to not making us happy with kind of what you're receiving from the spend. Could you comment on that?
componenttext: So that lower ad spend I believe that Investor Day, you alluded to not making us happy with kind of what you're receiving from the spend. Could you comment on that?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: It was less about being comfortable with the yield on the ad spend. It was our decisions here in the third quarter were more trying to make certain that we get to the profit objective, that 96 ratio that we talked about quite frequently and want to meet.
componenttext: It was less about being comfortable with the yield on the ad spend. It was our decisions here in the third quarter were more trying to make certain that we get to the profit objective, that 96 ratio that we talked about quite frequently and want to meet. So it's was conscious decision more there than the yield or the acquisition cost for the cost of sale versus targeted cost of sale is slightly higher than our targeted but that was a real driver the real driver is trying to ensure that we meet 96 ratio for the year.

componenttext: Our next question is from Vinay Misquith with Evercore Partners.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the expense ratio in the advertising, expenses once again. So the expense ratio within the Direct platform have averaged roughly to 20% to 21% over the last few years, that spike for the last couple of years up to around 22%. What do
componenttext: Just to follow up on the expense ratio in the advertising, expenses once again. So the expense ratio within the Direct platform have averaged roughly to 20% to 21% over the last few years, that spike for the last couple of years up to around 22%. What do you think is the more normalized rate? I mean, this year the expense ratio within that channel has come down. So would you think roughly 21% is the more normal ratio or is it the 22%?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well it's tough to say normal. Here's what I would tell you would be the drivers. When we talked about this a fair amount in terms of our ad spend, [indiscernible] overall profit targets we would base it upon what we get in terms of our acquisition costs,
componenttext: Well it's tough to say normal. Here's what I would tell you would be the drivers. When we talked about this a fair amount in terms of our ad spend, [indiscernible] overall profit targets we would base it upon what we get in terms of our acquisition costs, cost for so good the targeted comfortable with that, we'll keep spending. If we go above it, by a lots, we would've been revisited dose spend levels. And so when we do that on a regular basis. It could be roughly quarter and it to read that we're that. So that would be 1 component piece. And so it's pretty dynamic. We believe as we are much more comfortable with our aggregate rate accuracy that we will actually go back to higher levels of ad spend. So will see how that plays out. But that is the thought at least right now, that although third quarter was down and fourth quarter is likely to be a little bit lower, we will return to higher ad level spend as we get more comfortable with our rate accuracy. The second component piece is what I mentioned in terms of gaining some leverage on fixed cost and other, call it, employee compensation cost, et cetera. We've got, over time, we definitely aspire to grow earned premium growth in the faster levels from those cost. So that should have a long-term decrease in terms of our cost structure, both in LAE and expense ratio. And then the final thing, which is very, very important in of the direct channel is the new mix because remember, we have a very targets for new business versus real new business and we allocate all of our advertising costs in the business. If we don't get as much a new business, yes, we would reduce or adjust our advertising spend. If we are getting the growth, that referred to earlier, we will continue to spend as long as we're meeting that new business target on renewal business so I'd say it's a combination of great accuracy we did spend more other expenses, long-term we actually hope to gain some leverage on. So what will the run rate expense ratio be for Direct going forward, I think it's a combination of those effects. But that so. . .

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. The other question was really on the margin of safety. So what it is a management has always said you have a 96% target on the combined ratio but historically have had a margin of that combined ratio being closer to 92%, 93%. With the introdu
componenttext: Fair enough. The other question was really on the margin of safety. So what it is a management has always said you have a 96% target on the combined ratio but historically have had a margin of that combined ratio being closer to 92%, 93%. With the introduction of Snapshot, do you think that you can now reduce the margin of safety because you can now model your business better or do you think you still have to keep the historical margin on safety?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Vinay, sort of take into the margin of safety issue is your calling it's a 92%, when the marketplace is such that I don't want to give a long history of life, the marketplace has acted the way it has for the last decade or so, but certainly when it's avai
componenttext: Vinay, sort of take into the margin of safety issue is your calling it's a 92%, when the marketplace is such that I don't want to give a long history of life, the marketplace has acted the way it has for the last decade or so, but certainly when it's available to us, we will continue to grow and if we can make a 92% or 93%, then that's a combination we would accept if the market additions were favorable to do so I think what I've been saying for quite some time now is the market conditions are much more in the photo that we will be closer to our 96% to be able to continue to grow. So think of us not so much is trying to build in a safety margin but trying to be as aggressive in the marketplace as possible but put a very high premium on attending our 96% or better. Snapshot really doesn't change that. We're pricing Snapshot product or the discounted that we embed from Snapshot so that we hit exactly the same type of targets. Giving discounts is a very, very tricky thing. You're clearly reducing the margin on that particular or price on that particular customer, but we expect to make the same margin. So I would encourage you don't think about sort of a 92%, 93% as some act of a built-in safety margin I think of as for what we see we are going to try to grow as fast as possible it's a 96 and everything we do whether it's Snapshot or new price or anything else, we design to meet the same targets.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Josh Shanker with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from Josh Shanker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Looking at the Q, I see a combination of things, one is that your new applications after being up for the first half of the year has shifted down I wonder if you could comment on whether it's accelerating or whether negative 4% given the new rate is kind
componenttext: Looking at the Q, I see a combination of things, one is that your new applications after being up for the first half of the year has shifted down I wonder if you could comment on whether it's accelerating or whether negative 4% given the new rate is kind of where it stands? And two, it's difficult for me to turn renewal application growth into a retention statistics, you guys are bigger company anywhere a year ago. Are retention the more or less the same a year ago or something changed?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Joshua, new applications, you're right, clearly the rate pressure, I mean pretty simple physics took rates up, we see the effect of new apps. The 4% that we put there not going to forecast it but until we see some competitive actions that are even stronge
componenttext: Joshua, new applications, you're right, clearly the rate pressure, I mean pretty simple physics took rates up, we see the effect of new apps. The 4% that we put there not going to forecast it but until we see some competitive actions that are even stronger than the ones we've seen and clearly we are seeing competitive actions that are in the vast majority of cases, positive but I xpect that we will see, for some time, pressure on the new applications I'm not going to give a estimate of what that will be, but that's not going to turn around any time soon that will take a little bit of a market for us. Given that we're going to continue to focus on our target margins, we are very comfortable with that trade-off. Renewal apps, yes, you see a there's a sort of the reason that will be were obviously putting on the new business coming through is renewals. With not -- we don't give you specific by different classes of business. But we've given some indication that at least for our Agency book of business, life expectancy is actually increasing and for our Direct book, which had actually been experiencing some negative, it is now much more of a flat PLE. So while there will be a delayed effect on that as well and I'm not going to forecast exactly what that will be, as of right now, we're very comfortable with our retention statistics for the customers that have actually experienced rate increases as well. New business probably more concerning and I expect that, that will turn around at some point but I'm not going to forecast that point.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let's break it into 2 pieces of, Direct piece and our Agency piece. And I don't want to sort of a necessarily recounts any statements that might have been made but actually were quite comfortable with what's happening on certainly the direct side, recogni
componenttext: Let's break it into 2 pieces of, Direct piece and our Agency piece. And I don't want to sort of a necessarily recounts any statements that might have been made but actually were quite comfortable with what's happening on certainly the direct side, recognize that one of the key objectives there would like to bring in the new business with but one of the things you've always set out to do is make sure we don't lose current business that we have when there is a life change that requires some home policy. And about 50% of our business in the are our own customers maturing into greater insurance needs and is being able to accommodate them it. So frankly, very happy with it PHA on the Direct side. Second point would be on the Agency said that, we're -- we're very clearly said, we did not get out of the box, a good solution for agents, the company was fined, it just wasn't suited for agents. As you know announced in June of that we've entered into a relationship, significant relationship, with ASI relatively small company. But the very much in tune with culturally with where we are and the sort of things we want to achieve for our agents. We've been taking over the last several months the notion of Progressive and ASI as a little bit -- a lot more of an integrated offering for agents, clearly, not the same as it came from 1 company. But in this case, 2 companies that are very, very good at what they do, coming together, providing some, not only technology integrate the product but actually some product features and that is being very well received by agents are you presently being out talking to agency done conference calls with agents, I think this is something new to the marketplace in a sense that 2 very well-respected companies coming together putting their offerings together in that's actually are designed for agents and we are actually too early to sort of give you a lot of the metrics of what's happening there. We do have agency selection there where, not necessarily giving that are too all agents and we are looking for agents who have a very preferred book of business to be able to give us from a new business perspective and we are seeing early signs that agents, certain agents, not all, are appealing that this is a very viable solution for them, and we're very, very optimistic about the future of that hideous of Progressive relationship. That is going to be strong for some time recognize this it is of the preferred customers who are looking for home and auto is about 43% of the marketplace. Actually, I could even make that a little higher the way we defined things. But it's a big chunk of the marketplace that we have extraordinary low penetration in. And agents have a very large part of that marketplace. So for us to be able to be on the verge of taking something to agents, really that's give them the opportunity to have a coordinated bundle of home and auto is actually very exciting I think that excitement is spilling over from agents. So that question will be a good question. We'll have more data on exactly how Progressive a year from now. But I would say that's a very optimistic part of our outlook for next year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: What are your observations on hurricane Sandy? And what would you like investors to know as it relates to auto insurance in general? And specifically, Progressive?
componenttext: What are your observations on hurricane Sandy? And what would you like investors to know as it relates to auto insurance in general? And specifically, Progressive?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think we all want to know sort of where Sandy settles out and I'm sure every insurance company right now is giving best what they can. Let me tell you what I know and then try to avoid saying anything that we simply don't know. Overnight reporting
componenttext: Sure. I think we all want to know sort of where Sandy settles out and I'm sure every insurance company right now is giving best what they can. Let me tell you what I know and then try to avoid saying anything that we simply don't know. Overnight reporting, is that this probably bumped us up to about 6,000 claims so we've got the 6,000 claims that's a little higher than the number I would add last night but I suspect that's well on its way to that number. I think of that is 2/3 flood, 1/3 wind, about just sort of 80% of it is New York, New Jersey the rest would be another 10% Pennsylvania, or Connecticut and then obviously all the states that you all know were affected. That's sort of what we know right now. Spud claims for us probably going to be more often than not total losses. So order is not good for cars. So we have some estimates. We don't know exactly where and we have great models. But all models are exactly that. We don't know whether reporting will end. If we advantage for you and for us. We will release results in about 12 days or whatever that is 12 or 15 days from something like that for October. And literally, every hour goes by, the development of claim reporting is helping us. So we actually have a pretty good estimate of our exposure by the time we produce results in 12 or 13 days. So far, 6,000 claims, I don't want to even speculate as though we're that is. If I give you sort of a ballpark thing, you take the take it wrong way but it suspect seeing half of the things we're getting or in that neighborhood. So but there are people clearly as we all know with all power and so and so forth. So things might be a little bit different than we experienced as you would expect from Progressive and hopefully all other insurance companies at this point. The job #1 is getting everybody back to the conditions that they can move on with their lives. So we have deployed and we are active as you would expect in the marketplace with resources and doing a great job for the people that have reported their claims and hopefully we can get as many as unreported claims in within the next few days we can get on those as quickly as possible. Hopefully for any of you listening that were affected by the storms, hopefully you're able to get your lives back to situation that's comfortable for you or your family to whatever. So that's events insurance companies I think in general are stepping up and Enola Progressive. Up really well.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012

componenttext: Great. Completely unrelated, the investment portfolio. What have been your actions considering the low interest rate environment? And what should we think of in terms of strategy going forward?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's fair. We have Bill on the line so I'll let him take us through that.
componenttext: That's fair. We have Bill on the line so I'll let him take us through that.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Our actions have been consistent with what they've been historically, which is to try to look for value where we see it. We're not trying to hit the yield bogey, which is something nice about the way run things here is there's no pressure to try to
componenttext: Sure. Our actions have been consistent with what they've been historically, which is to try to look for value where we see it. We're not trying to hit the yield bogey, which is something nice about the way run things here is there's no pressure to try to stretch to reach some artificial or hope for number. We take what's available. And for us, that's been trying to find spread product primarily in, say, corporate or muni or CBS or sectors like that, that that offers a reasonable relative value and some reasonable absolute value as well. That's a become a little bit harder to find as spreads have come in from all sectors. But so in all, we have found a few packets to invest in and where we see those opportunities, we'll take them and when we don't, we don't feel pressured to put money to work and take risk that we don't think are appropriate to take.
